div.head: Private Compilations of Ruskinʼs Poems before 1850
div.p: In March 1847, when John James Ruskin wrote to his friend, W. H. Harrison (ca. 1792–1878), to affirm his intention to have a collection of his son's poems printed, he referred to having "had for a very long time a Volume of yours containing some light pieces of my son." Before the Poems (1850) was realized, in other words, the Ruskin circle produced and made use of compilations of Ruskin's poems (Leeds, 8 March 1847, in Letters from John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison, 1838–1853). The volume mentioned in this letter probably refers to a present from Harrison to John James for the holiday season of Christmas 1844 and New Yearʼs 1845.

On 4 January 1845, while spending a disagreeably unseasonal holiday at the seaside with his family in Hastings, John James Ruskin thanked Harrison for the “trouble you have taken to get me a Set of JR. F.O contributions”, referring to his son by the pen name used for most of his contributions to annuals (letter, in John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison, 1838–1853). The current location of this volume, if extant, is unknown, so its contents cannot now be determined. If limited, as John James indicates, to contributions to Friendshipʼs Offering, the choice was logical as a gift from the former editor (1836–41) of the annual, who grew particularly close to the Ruskin family during that tenure. It is perhaps no coincidence that the holiday season of Harrison's gift marked the end of Ruskin's regular appearances in Friendshipʼs Offering, in the volumes for 1835 through 1844. Poems by J.R. apppeared instead in two annuals edited by Lady Blessington for Longmans, as discussed below.

Possibly the “set” described by John James was the collection of ʼproofs of Ruskinʼs contributions to Friendshipʼs Offeringʽ that, according to the editors of the Library Edition, Harrison ʼbound upʽ for John James to carry ʼon his toursʽ (Ruskin, Works, 2:xxxiv). If so, this volume would have been bound in a size convenient for transport; it would also have been welcome to John James for ease of reference. As he commented later in the year to Harrison, John James was often frustrated by “the Scatterment” of his sonʼs poems published in annuals over several years; it was “the Looking for the needle in the Bundle of Hay I dislike—I know not how to have him or where to find him” (Liverpool, 1 July 1845, in Letters from John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison; and see Dearden, “Production and Distribution of John Ruskinʼs Poems 1850”, 154).

Another compilation that may have pre‐existed the project of collecting and printing Ruskinʼs poems for private circulation in 1850 is the manuscript, “J. Ruskin | Poems” (n.d.), or “Edmond manuscript”, a bound volume of holograph transcriptions of poems published in Friendshipʼs Offering. As a holograph manuscript, it does not answer to the Library Editionʼs description of Harrisonʼs bound proofs. It also lacks transcriptions of poems that, in addition to those appearing in Friendshipʼs Offering, were published in 1839 in the London Monthly Miscellany (see Ruskin, Works, 38:5). Since this magazine also was edited by Harrison, the omission seems notable if the volume is imagined as originating with him.

The hand responsible for the “Edmond manuscript” has not been identified; however, the physical item makes a good fit with circumstances mentioned by John James in his 8 March 1847 letter to Harrison announcing his intention to have Ruskin's poems printed. After referring to Harrison's "volume", John James goes on: "I have delayed having them [John's "verses"] penned because I want to get the best of all he has ever penned selected & printed in good Type." The penning clearly refers to a copyist's work at the behest of John James, which may have been related to publication plans. Harold Shapiro, in his edition of Ruskin's letters from Italy in 1845, speculates that John James used such procedures with the intention of publishing John's letters as an epistolary travel narrative: "He carefully preserved them, of course, and put them in order. More than that, the originals are full of his markings. He numbered them, supplied missing dates and places in the headings, made notations on them for a copyist, underlined the passages to be copied, cancelled details to be omitted, and even inserted a word here and there" (Shapiro, introduction to Ruskin in Italy, xx). While no such editorial markings by John James are evident in the “Edmond manuscript”, its very exacting transcriptions might represent a stage in the evolving plans toward a printed volume; and while obviously not a "delayed" transcription, it would have been a faulty effort for John James's requirements in 1847. As explained in the description of the manuscript, the transcriptions are not "selected"--starting, as they do, with "Saltzburg", Ruskin's first poem published in Friendshipʼs Offering, which was not ultimately chosen for inclusion in the Poems (1850)--and the sequence founders owing to a mistake in transcription of the poems for 1842. Even if not related directly to the project of printing the Poems in 1850, however, the manuscript attests at the very least to the interest before 1850 in collecting Ruskinʼs poems scattered throughout published annuals.

div.head: John James Ruskinʼs Reaction to Ruskinʼs Abandonment of a Poetʼs Vocation
div.p: In 1845, the need “to have these trifles more comeatable—less scattered” came to seem more pressing to John James, as four new poems by John were sent to Lady Blessington, who divided them between two annuals under her editorship, The Keepsake, 1846 and Heathʼs Book of Beauty, 1846, as she had done with three poems by Ruskin in the previous year. “You know we centred all in F. O.”, John James reminded Harrison, referring to the long run of poems by J.R. published in the Smith, Elder annual. John James pointed out that it would be “no joke” having to present each of many friends with two annuals for the year—and those two nothing less than the grand and expensive publications superintended for Longmans by the daring entrepreneur, Charles Heath (1785–1848), as compared with the familiar and less imposing annual produced by the Ruskinsʼ friends at Smith, Elder (Liverpool, 29 June 1845, in Letters from John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison, 1838–1853; and see Hunnisett, Steel‐Engraved Book Illustration in England, 142–43).

A more worrying prospect to John James than the expense of holiday gifts, however, and a more emotional cause for collecting the poems for publication in 1850, was that the poems were becoming less important to Ruskin himself. Already, the poems collected in Harrisonʼs 1845 gift compilation led to some affectation of indifference, “some in this House [having] had no recollection of having before seen” certain poems, although considerably connected with the Author” (Denmark Hill, 31 January 1845, in Letters from John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison, 1838–1853). Ruskin grew more outspoken about losing interest in verse composition after he departed for Italy in April 1845, his first Continental tour without his parentsʼ direct supervision, in order to study the Old Masters in preparation for completing the second volume of Modern Painters. While continuing to oblige his father by sending home new poems, Ruskin paraded his indifference: “Of course do all that you like with poems. Lady B[lessington] just as good as any one. I have neither pride nor pleasure in them”. Writing less flippantly on his fatherʼ birthday, he explained that his poetical impulse was being displaced by a critical temper: “I almost always see two sides of a thing at once, now—in matters poetical—& I never get strongly excited without perceiving drawbacks & imperfections which somehow one lost sight of when one was younger” (Florence, 13 June 1845, and Lucca, 10 May 1845, in Shapiro, ed., Ruskin in Italy, 112–13, 57).

John James himself was not pleased by Johnʼs recently composed poems and prayed that “his Mother may not be right after all & our Son prove but a poet in prose” (Kendal, 16 July 1845, in Letters from John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison, 1838–1853). After temporizing with the hope that it was only “at present” in 1845 that Johnʼs “poetry . . . has got among [his] prose”, and confessing to John that “it is cruel in me to ask you to write for me—you should never write Poetry but when you cannot help it”—by the following year John James had to “put an end to doubt as to annuals” and admit to Harrison that “my Son seems disposed to shake hands & part from” such publications altogether. By 1847, John James was resolved that the time had arrived to collect the poems formally as “a family Record” for private distribution (John James Ruskin to John Ruskin, 26 June 1845, in Shapiro, ed., Ruskin in Italy, 142 n. 2; and John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison, Florence, 20 June 1846, and Leeds, 8 March 1847, in Letters from John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison, 1838–1853, in and see Dearden, “Production and Distribution of John Ruskinʼs Poems 1850”, 155).

div.head: Selection of the Poems
div.p: The collection would not be comprehensive even as a record of published poetry; rather, “the best of all [John] has ever penned” in verse should be “selected & printed in a good Type” Besides the focus on Friendshipʼs Offering poems—which do predominate in Poems by J.R. (1850), albeit not exclusively—another decision weighing against inclusion of “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water” was a preference for more mature poetry. At first, in an 1850 letter to his son, who was working in Venice, John James proposed opening the volume with some poems composed at age twelve, which were family favorites; and he pressed his son to decide also if he wanted “any few lines in the under 10 Little Book to put in.” By a “Little Book,” John James must refer to one of the Red Books composed prior to age ten. Then on the next day (Ruskinʼs birthday), before Ruskin could have replied to this previous letter, his father all but overruled the inclusion of early juvenilia, informing his son that “[w]e shall not print your 12 year [i.e., age twelve] poems which tho marvellous are better in your own printed written [i.e., hand‐lettered] little Book—We shall begin with [the poem] Months age 16 [i.e., 1835–36] I believe unless you desire earlier pieces” (London, 1 February 1850 [MSL 002/003/096], and London, 2 February 1850 [MSL 002/003/097], in Letters from John James Ruskin to John Ruskin, 1829–1862, both letters quoted in Dearden, “Production and Distribution of John Ruskinʼs Poems 1850”, 156–57). (For “The Months” see “As I was walking round by Peckham rye”, from which this poem was derived and published in Friendshipʼs Offering for 1836 [i.e., in late 1835]. While “The Months” did not finally head the contents of Poems by J.R. (1850), the volume did start with poems largely from 1835–36, with the exception of “Song”, based on a previously unpublished poem of 1833, “Song” (“I weary for the torrent leaping”). The latter little poem opens the volume.)
